snippet: While many Muslims were upset by the caricatures of Muhammad in Charlie Hebdo, the origins of their objection to visual depictions of the prophet and holy persons of any faith are far from clear.
abstract: Islamic scholars and legal experts are examining Muslim claims that creating images of Prophet Muhammad is form of idol worship that demeans God; experts say that both origins and extent of decree are subject to question, in particular assertions that image-making is punishable by violence or death; debate follows terrorist attack on French newspaper Charlie Hebdo.
lead_paragraph: While many Muslims were upset by the caricatures of Muhammad in Charlie Hebdo, the origins of their objection to visual depictions of the prophet and holy persons of any faith are far from clear.

headline.main: Attack Raises Questions on Roots of Muslim Objection to Image-Making
headline.print_headline: Attack Raises Questions on Roots of Muslim Objection to Image-Making
